text:
The biggest poison in the Slovenian mindset is the belief that the "State" will provide. It‚Äôs a hangover from the past‚Äîa safety net that has made us mentally soft.

We look at the US and ask why they dominate. It‚Äôs simple: Their DNA is built on risk. Our DNA is built on safety. We have stayed in the same spot for a thousand years, waiting for handouts, while they crossed oceans to build something from nothing.

We need to stop acting like victims and start acting like Spartans.

We are a small nation. We cannot win on volume (like China). We cannot win on mass production. We must win on Elite Quality.

Look at our athletes. They are the proof. A nation of 2 million people dominating the world stage. Why? Because in sports, you can‚Äôt fake it. You either perform, or you lose.

We need to transfer that "Spartan" DNA into business and technology.

The Goal: The Taiwan Strategy. We don‚Äôt need to be big.We need to be indispensable. We need to identify a niche, dominate it completely, and make the world dependent on us. That is true security. That is true power.

Stop waiting for the government to give you "free AI" or better policies. The State is just a reflection of the people. If you want a better State, become a better operator.

Life is not about comfort. Comfort is stagnation. Life is about the glory of overcoming the impossible.

Dream bigger. Risk more.

text:
If you are paying for an "AI Automation Workshop," you are failing the IQ test.

My feed is infested with parasites selling n8n and Make dot com courses to terrified CEOs and incompetent CTOs paralyzed by FOMO.

Let‚Äôs be clear: These "influencers" are selling you snake oil. They don‚Äôt understand engineering. They don‚Äôt understand architecture. They are just capitalizing on your laziness and your fear of falling behind.

If you are a "CTO" and you are buying these courses, turn in your badge. You are asleep at the wheel. You don‚Äôt need a guru to hold your hand.

You want a reality check?

My grandmother is using ChatGPT. She didn't even own a smartphone 3 years ago. Now she is prompting LLMs.

And I know what the "experts" will say: "Oh, but be careful! AI hallucinates! What if your granny asks for a recipe and it tells her to cook poison?"

I don't care.

You want to talk about hallucinations? Books hallucinate. Who do you think wrote the books? People. And people hallucinate their own reality every single day. Authors have egos. Experts have biases. We are all hallucinating in our own worlds.

If my grandmother can figure this out without a $2,000 "Masterclass," what is your excuse?

You don‚Äôt need a "certification." You need a spine and an internet connection.

We have the most powerful intelligence in human history available for $20/month. Stop funding the mediocrity industrial complex. Kill the FOMO.

Build it yourself or get out of the way.

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 3 weeks ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Following my last post, I want to share what we actually built at the Hack the Future hackathon.

‚ÄãWe competed in the AI & Insurtech challenge, tackling a problem we believe is universal.

Companies are struggling to make internal AI assistants (like Copilot) work.

‚ÄãThe Problem:
Many companies try to dump their entire knowledge base (all documents, all policies) into a single, massive LLM.

The result? Constant halucinations, "context bleeding" (e.g., a car insurance query getting answers from a life insurance policy), and zero traceability. 

This approach fails.
‚Äã
Our Solution:
We didn't build a single "all-knowing" bot. We built an AI Agentic System based on a hierarchy of specialists.

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄãOrchestrator Agent: The "manager" that first analyzes a user's query.

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄãSpecialist Agents: The Orchestrator then routes the query to a specialist (e.g., "Auto Insurance Agent," "Internal Process Agent").

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄãSpecialized Knowledge: Critically, each agent has its own, isolated vector database. The auto agent cannot see the life insurance docs. This is the key to eliminating hallucinations.

‚Ä¢ ‚ÄãSupervisor Agent: A final "compliance" agent that validates the answer before it's shown to the user.

‚Äã"But isn't a multi-agent system expensive and slow?"

‚ÄãThis is the most exciting part. It's not. This architecture is more efficient by using smaller, powerful open-source models. 

Specialist agents built on models like DeepSeek-R1 or the new Kimi K2 (K2) are designed for this.

They can outperform giant, proprietary models on narrow tasks‚Äîdelivering faster, cheaper, and more accurate results.

‚ÄãWe believe this‚Äîa system of specialists, not a "one-model-to-rule-them-all" approach‚Äîis the real key to unlocking reliable enterprise AI.

My team Asteras.ai and I didn't win the hackathon and it was a necessary cold shower.

‚ÄãWe were 100% focused on building a robust, functional MVP, but we completely overlooked one of the most critical parts: the pitch.

‚ÄãIt's a tough, but invaluable, lesson.

We learned that the best product doesn't win; the best story about the product does.

‚ÄãWe gained a ton of experience, new respect for the art of storytelling, and a laser focus on what to master next.

Huge respect for my team, An≈æe Skralovnik and ≈Ωan Lah.

I'm extremely proud of what we built under pressure. We‚Äôll get the next one.

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Most people are still hyping LLMs and RAG.

Cool ‚Äî but that‚Äôs entry level.

Here‚Äôs the real hierarchy of AI üëá
1Ô∏è‚É£ LLM Workflow ‚Üí basic text prediction. Good for email drafts and chatbots.
2Ô∏è‚É£ RAG ‚Üí better Q&A because you add external data. Still brittle.
3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Agent ‚Üí planning + reasoning + tools. Now you‚Äôre automating workflows.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Agentic AI ‚Üí multi-agent swarms. Specialized roles, memory, collaboration. 

This is where scale and real disruption happens.

Notice the pattern?
Every step adds structure and autonomy.
Every step pushes humans further out of the loop.

üëâ That‚Äôs why "just RAG" shops won‚Äôt survive. They‚Äôll be leapfrogged by agentic systems that don‚Äôt just answer ‚Äî they act.

Your move:
Are you still wiring prompts into RAG pipelines‚Ä¶ or are you already building swarms?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
This place worships kind leadership.

ü§ù Empathy. Soft skills. Being nice.

But here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth‚ö°

Every legendary founder I‚Äôve studied looked nothing like that.
üèπ Larry Ellison (Oracle) ‚Äì combative, fearless.
üçè Steve Jobs (Apple) ‚Äì perfectionist, demanding.
üì¶ Jeff Bezos (Amazon) ‚Äì relentless, feared.
üçî Ray Kroc (McDonald‚Äôs) ‚Äì ruthless scaler.
üöó Elon Musk (Tesla/SpaceX) ‚Äì relentless, uncompromising.

They‚Äôre brutal. üî• Screaming. Demanding. Obsessive.

And when you dig into the real stories ‚Äî it‚Äôs true. They didn‚Äôt succeed because they were polite.

They succeeded because they refused to accept anything less than their vision. üöÄ

So here‚Äôs the paradox:
üëâ Does greatness in building come because of that tyrant energy‚Ä¶ or despite it?

I don‚Äôt have the final answer. But I do know this: the fire, the obsession, the refusal to compromise ‚Äî it‚Äôs in every story.

‚ùìWhat do you think ‚Äî are we romanticizing toxic leadership, or is this just the reality of building something world-changing?

These movies aren‚Äôt just entertainment. They spark that ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment, they make you rethink ambition, risk, and what it takes to build.

I dug into the repo. It‚Äôs not hype ‚Äî it‚Äôs practical:
üí¨ ask endpoint ‚Üí query your site in plain language
 üîÑ Schema.org / RSS / JSON Feed ‚Üí reuse what you already have
 üóÑÔ∏è Slots right into vector DBs (Qdrant, Milvus, Azure AI Search, Postgres, etc.)

What this means for you:

 üéØ Agents can find, understand, and act on your data without custom APIs
 üöÄ You stop fighting SEO checkboxes and start building AIO ‚Äî Agent Input Optimization

Stop thinking ‚Äúchatbot on top.‚Äù Start thinking natural language as a first-class API. üß©

And yes ‚Äî NLWeb plays with MCP/A2A, not against them:
üîß MCP wires your tools/prompts/resources
 ü§úü§õ A2A lets agents collaborate
 üåç NLWeb makes your website agent-ready

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Most teams still wire ‚Äúone big agent‚Äù to a pile of tools.

Cute. But the real game? Agents talking to agents.

That‚Äôs A2A (Agent-to-Agent Protocol https://lnkd.in/dNhNv82E) ‚Äî an open spec (Google + 50+ partners) for interoperability. Not another wrapper. A common language so your sourcing agent briefs your CRM agent, which syncs with your scheduling agent, while compliance oversees it all.

What A2A standardizes:
üëâ Agent Cards ‚Üí agents advertise skills, auth, endpoints.
üëâ Tasks ‚Üí Artifacts ‚Üí workflows with state + outputs, not one-shots.
üëâ Collaboration Messages ‚Üí context exchange, not duct-taped webhooks.
üëâ UX Negotiation ‚Üí text, forms, files, audio, video.
üëâ Enterprise rails ‚Üí HTTP, JSON-RPC, SSE.
üëâ Opaque by design ‚Üí no secret-sauce leaks.

How it fits with MCP:
MCP = connect agents to tools/resources (inside).
A2A = connect agents to each other (outside).

Winners won‚Äôt build ‚Äúsuper agents.‚Äù They‚Äôll orchestrate specialists via A2A ‚Äî measurable, swappable, secure.

So‚Ä¶ are you still shipping solo agents, or designing for multi-agent markets?
Drop your first A2A use-case. If it‚Äôs ‚Äúlater,‚Äù you‚Äôre already late. üöÄ

article.subtitle: developers.googleblog.com

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Everyone talks about MCP like it‚Äôs just a tool connector.
Wrong. That‚Äôs only the surface. ‚ö°

When I first looked into MCP, I went straight to the official docs (https://lnkd.in/dKwnKx9G). And that‚Äôs where it hit me. üí°

MCP isn‚Äôt just about plugging APIs into your LLM.
It‚Äôs a protocol with layers:
  - Resources ‚Üí structured context injection
  - Prompts ‚Üí reusable prompt libraries, standard across clients
  - Tools ‚Üí yes, the obvious one, but only part of the puzzle
  - Discovery ‚Üí how agents actually find what they can use
  - Sampling ‚Üí steering how responses get generated
  - Roots ‚Üí defining what‚Äôs possible in the environment
  - Elicitation ‚Üí shaping how agents extract data from humans

Most current clients only bother with Tools. That‚Äôs why people think MCP = tool calling.

But the real power? When all these components come together ‚Äî a shared language for how AI agents access, use, and expand their world.

This is bigger than ‚ÄúLLM wrappers.‚Äù
It‚Äôs an operating system for agents. üñ•Ô∏è ü§ñ

Question is:
Do you see MCP evolving into the TCP/IP of the AI era ‚Äî invisible but everywhere?
Or will it stay a niche toy for the builders paying attention right now?
I know where I‚Äôm placing my bet. What about you?

 99% have no clue how they actually work.

Reality check:
If you‚Äôre just prompting ChatGPT ‚Äî you‚Äôre babysitting a chatbot, not building an agent.

The 5 real design patterns:
 1Ô∏è‚É£ Reflection ‚Üí Checks its own work, iterates.
 2Ô∏è‚É£ Tool Use ‚Üí Calls APIs, databases, code.
 3Ô∏è‚É£ ReAct ‚Üí Think ‚Üí Act ‚Üí Observe ‚Üí Repeat.
 4Ô∏è‚É£ Planning ‚Üí Breaks problems into steps, executes.
 5Ô∏è‚É£ Multi-agent ‚Üí A team of specialists working in sync.

This is the playbook.
Miss it, and you‚Äôre building toys while others build systems that take markets.

üëâ Still hacking prompts? Or building scalable agents?

üß≠ Planning is the underrated superpower of AI agents.

The fix? Planning.
 ‚Üí Set the goal

That‚Äôs how you turn chatbots into project managers.

Scalable. Reliable. Flexible.
Not sexy ‚Äî but the difference between toy demos and production.

text:
The old e-commerce playbook is about to get torched.

For 20 years, merchants obsessed over funnels, landing pages, and checkout hacks. üöÄ Useless once AI agents start buying, not just recommending.

That‚Äôs what the Agentic Commerce Protocol (ACP) does (https://lnkd.in/dgYHZnHE) ‚Äî an open-source spec (Apache 2.0) backed by OpenAI + Stripe.

 ‚úÖ ChatGPT can alrevady check out with merchants inside chat.
 ‚úÖ Shopify + Etsy stores can apply with no extra integration.
 ‚úÖ Works with digital goods, physical, subscriptions, async orders.

üëâ Merchant sign-up + details are live here: https://lnkd.in/dc_rdR6g

Game-changer, right? Yes ‚Äî but with caveats:
 ‚ö†Ô∏è It‚Äôs still a draft. Early adopters may need rewrites.
 ‚ö†Ô∏è US-only (for now).
 ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù spec, but discovery + ranking will still be controlled.

If ACP sticks, your website won‚Äôt be the front door anymore.
Your customer will just say ‚Äúbuy this‚Äù to an AI.

So: are you ready for commerce without a website? Or do you think this is just hype?

Comment below ‚Äî I want to see who‚Äôs bold enough to bet on this.

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Most RAG is lazy:
Query ‚Üí Retrieve ‚Üí Pray.

Agentic RAG changes the game.
It doesn‚Äôt just fetch context ‚Äî it plans, tests, and fixes until the answer holds up.

Think loop, not line:
LLM ‚Üí Tool ‚Üí Check ‚Üí Refine ‚Üí Repeat.

What it adds:
 ‚ö° Rewrites bad queries, switches tools.
 ‚ö° Maker‚Äìchecker loop (generate ‚Üí verify ‚Üí fix).
 ‚ö° Multi-tool (vector, SQL, APIs, web).
 ‚ö° Memory (learns mid-run).
 ‚ö° Safe fails + human hand-off.

Where it shines:
- Compliance, legal, medical.
- NL2SQL without hallucinations.
- Long workflows that can‚Äôt afford mistakes.

If your ‚ÄúRAG‚Äù can‚Äôt ask for more info, change its plan, and prove its sources‚Ä¶
 It‚Äôs not agentic. It‚Äôs just a chatbot with a PDF fetish.

üëâ Who‚Äôs running Agentic RAG in prod ‚Äî and what did it replace? üöÄ

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
LLMs alone are useless.
They can talk, but they can‚Äôt do.

The unlock? Tools.
That‚Äôs what turns a chatbot into an agent.

Tool Use Pattern = backbone of every serious agent:
 ‚ö° Fetch data (stocks, weather, DBs)
 ‚ö° Execute (code, math, simulations)
 ‚ö° Automate (emails, tasks, workflows)
 ‚ö° Support (CRMs, tickets, KBs)

But tools need design:
- Schemas (so LLM knows what exists)
- Logic (when to call what)
- Error handling (because tools fail)
- State & memory (don‚Äôt lose context)

If your agent doesn‚Äôt use tools ‚Äî it‚Äôs just a chatbot in a costume.
üëâ First tool you‚Äôd wire in if you had to ship tomorrow?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Everyone obsesses over frameworks (LangChain, CrewAI, AutoGen).
Nobody talks about design.

Bad code slows you down.
Bad design kills trust instantly.

Agentic design = principles:
 ‚ö° Transparency ‚Üí always say it‚Äôs AI.
 ‚ö° Control ‚Üí let me shape or erase.
 ‚ö° Consistency ‚Üí don‚Äôt confuse with random UX.

Example: even a travel agent should say:
 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm AI. Here‚Äôs what I can do. Here‚Äôs how to edit me. Here‚Äôs how to delete my memory.‚Äù

Most ‚Äúagents‚Äù today? Spam, pop-ups, zero trust.

üëâ Who wins the race ‚Äî best models, or best design?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Framework wars are a distraction.

LangChain. AutoGen. CrewAI. Semantic Kernel.
Stop arguing. Start shipping.

Truth: frameworks don‚Äôt make agents smart. They just give you scaffolding:
 ‚ö° Orchestration
 ‚ö° Collaboration
 ‚ö° Memory
 ‚ö° Prod hygiene

Quick cheat sheet:

Prototype fast ‚Üí AutoGen, SmolAgents
Complex orchestration ‚Üí LangGraph, CrewAI
Enterprise guardrails ‚Üí Semantic Kernel, Azure Agent Service
General-purpose ‚Üí LangChain

If you‚Äôre still duct-taping scripts, you‚Äôre stuck in the tutorial.
Pick one. Ship. Break. Learn.

üëâ Which stack are you betting on in 2025?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Everyone screams ‚ÄúAI Agents‚Äù like it‚Äôs the next revolution.
But most people can‚Äôt even define what an agent actually is.
Here‚Äôs the truth: an AI Agent isn‚Äôt just an LLM with prompts.

It‚Äôs a system. With:
     - Environment ‚Üí the world it operates in
     - Sensors ‚Üí how it perceives what‚Äôs happening
     - Actuators ‚Üí how it acts to change that world
     - Memory + Knowledge ‚Üí short-term and long-term intelligence

That‚Äôs when LLMs stop being ‚Äúchatbots with nice answers‚Äù‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶and start actually doing work.

There are different breeds of agents too:
     - Reflex agents (just react)
     - Goal-based agents (plan)
     - Utility-based agents (optimize tradeoffs)
     - Learning agents (improve over time)
     - Multi-agent systems (work together or even compete)

So when does an agent make sense?
üëâ Open-ended problems (where you can‚Äôt hardcode every step)
üëâ Multi-step processes (complex workflows with tools + data)
üëâ Tasks that improve with feedback (real learning, not just parroting)

Here‚Äôs the kicker: 95% of ‚Äúagents‚Äù you see online aren‚Äôt agents at all. They‚Äôre just scripts chained together with marketing.

Want to really understand the difference?
This free course breaks it down: AI Agents for Beginners

I‚Äôm still connecting the dots myself ‚Äî but every lesson makes the hype less mysterious, and more buildable.
Are you willing to dig deeper, or stay on the surface?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Most people today ‚Äúbuild AI agents‚Äù in n8n or Make.
And that‚Äôs fine ‚Äî they ship fast, they deliver.

But here‚Äôs the truth: almost nobody actually understands what‚Äôs happening under the hood.

I didn‚Äôt want to just copy workflows. I wanted to know why this agentic hype works at all.

So I took this üëâ AI Agents for Beginners course by Microsoft (https://lnkd.in/de_ZfTEQ).
And it‚Äôs gold:
      - Clear breakdown of agentic AI architecture & design
      - How tools, memory, protocols (MCP, A2A, NLWeb), and infra really connect
      - Practical code examples across multiple languages & frameworks
      - Theory first ‚Üí then you spin it up locally and see it run

Now, I get it ‚Äî these courses are also a way for big cloud providers to push their infra, burn tokens, and lock you in.

But to be fair, this one felt surprisingly transparent. As an overview of the agentic hype, it actually delivers.

The wild part? The YouTube vids behind this course barely have 5k views. Almost nobody has touched it.

Most people just want to drive the car. I‚Äôm the guy who wants to open the hood, see the gears turning, and know why it runs.

So here‚Äôs my challenge:
Will you stay on the surface, stacking automations‚Ä¶ or will you actually understand how agents really work?

Your move. üöÄ

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Everyone talks about ‚ÄúAI agents.‚Äù
But under the hood? It‚Äôs just LLMs with a few tricks slapped on top.

Last week I went back to the foundations ‚Äî the real mechanics behind the hype:
    - Prompting (the art that separates average outputs from genius ones)
    - RAG (the hidden engine that makes AI actually useful)
    - Cloud + infra (the layer everyone ignores, but where the scale happens)

This free course üëâ Microsoft Generative AI for Beginners (https://lnkd.in/d_vYjgU9) might be a year old, but it‚Äôs still absolutely relevant. Updated, practical, and it builds the fundamentals you need before diving into advanced systems like multi-agent architectures.

Bonus: Anthropic‚Äôs Skilljar courses (https://lnkd.in/ddHq7H9C) ‚Äî crystal clear structure, perfect for nailing the basics.

Now, I get it. For most people, you don‚Äôt need to know how a car engine works if all you want is to drive. Same with AI ‚Äî tons of ‚Äúgurus‚Äù are building agencies on Make, n8n, and automations. And honestly, I respect that speed and execution.

But I‚Äôm just a curious guy ‚Äî like many of you here. I want to peek under the hood, see the gears turning, and understand why this stuff works.

My ‚Äúaha‚Äù? Realizing these are just techniques to make LLMs ‚Äî and other foundation models (image, video, etc.) ‚Äî more useful than before. Nothing else. Before, it was just magic. Now, it makes sense.

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Most people hide behind ‚Äúwaiting for the perfect idea.‚Äù
I didn‚Äôt. I shipped.

I joined the #nicehack69 Browser Use hackathon ‚Äî the rule: your project must actually use Browser-Use at its core.

Quick explainer: Browser-Use is an AI browser agent that automates real online tasks ‚Äî logging in, clicking, scraping, filling forms, comparing data. Basically, it kills repetitive browsing work.

My submission? Real Estate Agent üè°
Basically, a wrapper that lets AI crawl multiple property sites, extract listings, and show them side-by-side.
Not world-changing. Not polished. But it works.
üëâ Demo: https://lnkd.in/dPbj8gEN
üëâ Repo: https://lnkd.in/dD7ySyHy

Here‚Äôs the truth:
   - Yes, it‚Äôs ‚Äújust a wrapper.‚Äù
   - Yes, Browser-Use itself is doing the heavy lifting.
   - And yes, real use-cases with Browser-Use can get pricey ($1 per complex task isn‚Äôt crazy).

But none of that matters. What matters is: I stopped overthinking and published. That‚Äôs the muscle I‚Äôm training.

Too many of us sit on the sidelines waiting for a genius idea. The only way to find it? Ship the not-so-genius ones first.

text:

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

reshared_post.text:
üí° Slovenian vs English: how token-efficient are LLMs really?

I was curious how much more (or less) efficient AI models are when working in Slovenian compared to English. So I tested it with OpenAI‚Äôs Tokenizer tool: https://lnkd.in/d9Zqm2XN

Here‚Äôs what I found:
üá∏üáÆ Slovenian: 304 tokens per 1000 characters
üá¨üáß English: 181 tokens per 1000 characters
    üëâ That‚Äôs ~40% fewer tokens in English.

üìä For comparison:
    üá¨üáß English:
       1 token ‚âà ~4 characters
       1 token ‚âà ~¬æ of a word
       100 tokens ‚âà ~75 words
       1 paragraph ‚âà ~100 tokens
       1,500 words ‚âà ~2,048 tokens

   üá∏üáÆ Slovenian:
      1 token ‚âà ~3.3 characters
      1 token ‚âà ~¬Ω of a word
      100 tokens ‚âà ~50 words
      1 paragraph ‚âà 120‚Äì150 tokens
      1,500 words ‚âà ~3,000 tokens

At first this looks like a big gap ‚Äì more tokens mean:
        - Higher cost ‚Üí every request in Slovenian consumes more tokens.
        - Less context space ‚Üí fewer tokens left for documents / history.
        - Potentially weaker answers ‚Üí model runs ‚Äútighter‚Äù on context window.

But in practice, Slovenian still works fine for many local use cases (customer support, government services, education). English just gives you more ‚Äúroom‚Äù if you need large context or global knowledge.

üîë Takeaway: Token efficiency matters ‚Äì but usability in your native language matters too.

üëâ What do you think ‚Äì am I interpreting this right, or missing something? Would love to hear from others...

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
WhatsApp is built for control.
Telegram is built for growth.

When I hired an online fitness coach, all our chats ran through WhatsApp.
He had 100+ clients. His replies were slow. Naturally, I researched automation.

What I found?
WhatsApp Business API is fundamentally broken in Europe.

‚ùå No coexistence: you can‚Äôt use the app + API together (thanks, GDPR).
‚ùå Brutal pricing: after 24h, every message = Meta-approved template. Wrong category? You pay more.
‚ùå Awful UX: to ‚Äúgo API,‚Äù a coach would literally lose WhatsApp on his phone.
‚ùå No chat history access: you only get what‚Äôs coming in now. Old conversations? Manual export/import hell.

That‚Äôs not a business solution. That‚Äôs a nightmare.

Then I looked at Telegram. Different universe:
‚úÖ Unlimited messaging, no restrictions.
‚úÖ Bots with full automation: anything you can code, you can run directly inside the business chat.
‚úÖ Business accounts with bot backend: hook a bot to your account and it replies as you. No ‚Äúbot‚Äù label ‚Äî clients think they‚Äôre talking directly to you.
‚úÖ Mini-apps: dashboards, portals, even CRMs ‚Äî all inside Telegram.

Telegram isn‚Äôt ‚Äújust another chat app.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a platform. A business OS.

WhatsApp = legacy.
Telegram = future.

If you‚Äôre scaling communication, client support, or automation ‚Äî ask yourself:
üëâ Are you still building on sand, or are you ready to switch before you‚Äôre forced?

üìñ Full breakdown here: https://lnkd.in/di_eWnM2

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
I thought we nailed it.
We didn‚Äôt.

Three months ago I hired an online fitness coach.
100+ clients. Answers came days late. Burnout was obvious.

I pulled in a friend. We built him a solution:
‚ö° A digital twin that talked like him.
‚ö° Auto-generated diet & training plans.
‚ö° Coach only steps in for review ‚Äî 80% of work gone.

The ROI? Crystal clear.
More time. More clients. More money.

So we pitched him. Live. In Ljubljana.

He liked the idea.
But then came the price tag.
He couldn‚Äôt pay. Not because it wasn‚Äôt valuable ‚Äî but because he was a solo freelancer running on thin cash flow.

That‚Äôs when it hit me:
We didn‚Äôt fail on tech.
We failed on customer selection.

üëâ The right buyer pays 10x more for the same solution.
üëâ The wrong buyer can‚Äôt even start.

Our first big miss. But the lesson will stick forever.

Full story here: https://lnkd.in/drP7mbgK

So tell me ‚Äî are you building for the problem‚Ä¶ or for the buyer?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

article.title: The Missed Niche Lesson: Why Our First Big Pitch Failed
article.subtitle: vitosenic.com

posted_at.relative: 2 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Napoleon Hill said every great leader has a ‚Äúmastermind group.‚Äù
Advisors. Mentors. Giants in their corner.

So I built mine.
Not with humans. With AI.

Elon Musk. Larry Ellison. Jeff Bezos.
Personalities living inside ChatGPT.
Brutally honest feedback, different lenses, zero sugarcoating.

When I‚Äôm stuck, I don‚Äôt journal.
I sit down with my ‚Äúcouncil‚Äù and ask:
What would Musk do? What would Bezos cut? What would Larry kill?

It‚Äôs not about accuracy ‚Äî it‚Äôs about perspective.
Forcing my brain to think bigger. Sharper. Ruthless.

Call it delusional. Call it genius.
But I‚Äôd rather spar with billion-dollar mindsets than my own excuses.

üëâ Who would you add to your AI mastermind group?

text:
Portfolios are boring.
That‚Äôs why I killed mine.

Instead, I built vitosenic.com ‚Äî a site that talks back.
Minimal design. Lightning fast. And powered by an AI that actually answers as me.

Stack? Next.js. Supabase. GitHub Models.
Plus a RAG pipeline that auto-feeds new content ‚Äî notes, projects, CV ‚Äî straight into the chat. No manual updates. No stale pages.

This isn‚Äôt a portfolio.
It‚Äôs a living system.

Now imagine this at scale: a digital self that knows everything about you, sells for you, and solves problems while you sleep.

üëâ Full write-up of how I pulled it off: https://lnkd.in/dUmhWvsH
üëâ Or try it yourself: https://www.vitosenic.com/

Question is‚Ä¶ do you still want a portfolio, or do you want something that works while you sleep?

author.headline: AI Systems Architect | I connect business goals into working solutions.

posted_at.relative: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
Programming with AI is insanely fun. Process is:
1. generate code
2. read & understand code that was generated
3. make small changes "manually" (still with great autocomplete)
4. test & debug
5. make big changes with new prompt
6. go back to step 1

Pure vibe coding skips step 2 & 3. And I think we'll need human expertise & experience for steps 2, 3 (and 4) for quite a while.

But holy shit, I'm learning much faster, being way more productive, and having more fun.

Not sure we're close to "AGI/ASI", but the software engineering world is definitely getting transformed very rapidly. It feels surreal to be experiencing it directly on a daily basis. Of course, there are both scary (jobs, security) & exciting (productivity, access) consequences to this transformation, as with all powerful technology.

This post was fully written by human in one-shot without spellcheck, it's 100% organic human writing ü§£

author.headline: Research Scientist, MIT

posted_at.relative: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

text:
üöÄ Out of my comfort zone ‚Äî hitting publish.

I just finished reading Digital Fluency ‚Äî and it‚Äôs not the tech overviews that stuck with me, but the last chapter: ‚ÄúYour Digital Action Plan.‚Äù üìò

üí° 3 takeaways I‚Äôll actually use:
Tools ‚â† outcomes. Results come from org design, iteration cadence, and KPIs (buying an AI SaaS without process/KPIs = shelfware).

Enterprise vs small teams. Big firms need governance & change management; small teams win on speed‚Äîborrow just enough playbook to scale without chaos.

Tech-fit, quick map: repetitive knowledge work ‚Üí AI/copilots/agents ü§ñ (e.g., first-pass email drafts) ¬∑ many parties needing shared truth ‚Üí blockchain ‚õìÔ∏è (e.g., supplier ledger) ¬∑ quantum ‚ú® ‚Üí exciting, but early for most.

üîç What stood out: 
Many companies want to adopt AI or blockchain but quickly realise they lack the basic infrastructure ‚Äî clean, centralised data, integrated systems, and scalable cloud setups.

Without this foundation, these technologies become little more than fancy buzzwords for sales pitches.

üí∞ The real opportunity? Helping companies build that foundation ‚Äî and then unlocking the real value of advanced tech.

Even though the book was written in 2021 and the tech examples are dated, the decision-making frameworks are still timeless.

For the curious: üìò Digital Fluency‚Ä¶ (2021). Amazon: https://lnkd.in/dfRjMFcD
